docs.lead_paragraph: Corrections appearing in print on April 2, 2014.
docs.snippet: Corrections appearing in print on April 2, 2014.

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget resolution for 2015 will probably get full support from House Republicans, but voters should look closely at the details.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends Republican budget for 2015 released by Rep Paul Ryan is a document designed solely so that House Republicans can have something to show their most antigovernment voters in advance of midterm elections; criticizes details of the budget, and warns that Ryan could be very dangerous if he ends up securing chairmanship of the Ways and Means Committee.
docs.snippet: The budget resolution for 2015 will probably get full support from House Republicans, but voters should look closely at the details.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Politicians and policy makers have largely overlooked people who bought insurance outside the Affordable Care Act, even though they could influence the program’s financial success.

headline.main: Newly Enrolled, but Not Counted by Insurance Exchanges
headline.print_headline: Newly Enrolled, but Not Counted by Insurance Exchanges

docs.abstract: Some health care experts estimate that millions of newly insured people decided to bypass state and federal exchanges and purchase policies directly; overlooked group will nonetheless have a significant effect on the success of the Affordable Care Act, which depends upon an influx of healthy customers to offset cost of compliance.
docs.snippet: Politicians and policy makers have largely overlooked people who bought insurance outside the Affordable Care Act, even though they could influence the program’s financial success.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The announcement that 7.1 million people had signed up for plans under the Affordable Care Act came as the Obama administration braced for an escalated political battle ahead of the midterm elections.

headline.main: Obama Claims Victory in Push for Insurance
headline.print_headline: Obama Claims Victory in Push for Insurance

docs.abstract: Pres Obama declares victory in the government's aggressive push to enroll seven million people in private health insurance plans under the Affordable Care Act; Obama's senior aides brace for an escalated political battle over the law ahead of crucial midterm elections; milestone may be more significant politically than for its potential impact on the American health system, which remains unclear.
docs.snippet: The announcement that 7.1 million people had signed up for plans under the Affordable Care Act came as the Obama administration braced for an escalated political battle ahead of the midterm elections.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s plan, which increased defense spending and carved deeply from domestic programs, may serve as a guide for Republican candidates in this year’s coming elections.

headline.main: Ryan’s Budget Would Cut $5 Trillion in Spending Over a Decade
headline.print_headline: Ryan’s Budget Would Cut $5 Trillion in Spending Over a Decade

docs.abstract: Rep Paul D Ryan lays out new Republican budget plan that would cut $5 trillion in spending over the next decade; proposal redraws battle lines for the 2014 election, and details what his party could do with complete control of Congress.
docs.snippet: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s plan, which increased defense spending and carved deeply from domestic programs, may serve as a guide for Republican candidates in this year’s coming elections.

docs.lead_paragraph: The undisputed winners of a legislative battle over the nation’s tax code are the lobbying shops, which often work to simply preserve the status quo.

headline.main: Corporate Lobbyists Assail Tax Overhaul They Once Cheered
headline.print_headline: Lobbyists Who Once Cheered Tax Overhaul Now Work to Kill It

docs.abstract: Lobbying shops in Washington are seen as undisputed winners of legislative battle over nation’s tax code; after supporting 3-year overhaul to lower corporate tax rates, many are now working to make sure package never becomes law; twist reflects how tax lobbying is on the rise, with lobbying firms profiting enormously as corporations and groups registering to lobby on tax matters has surged.
docs.snippet: The undisputed winners of a legislative battle over the nation’s tax code are the lobbying shops, which often work to simply preserve the status quo.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hawaii isn't required to fund Medicaid for migrants from three Pacific Island nations in Micronesia to make up for a reduction in federal funding, a federal appeals court ruled Tuesday.

headline.main: Court: Hawaii Not Required to Pay for Migrant Care
headline.print_headline: Court: Hawaii Not Required to Pay for Migrant Care

docs.snippet: Hawaii isn't required to fund Medicaid for migrants from three Pacific Island nations in Micronesia to make up for a reduction in federal funding, a federal appeals court ruled Tuesday.
